title: Günther Oettinger rules out lobbying job for German carmakers
text:
'No,' Günther Oettinger said when asked whether he was being sought after to lead the powerful Berlin-based Association of the Automotive Industry (VDA) | Emmanuel Dunand/AFP via Getty Images Günther Oettinger rules out lobbying job for German carmakers The longtime supporter of the automotive industry says he had turned down such a job in the past.

Günther Oettinger is not set to become chief lobbyist for the German car industry after he leaves his post at the European Commission, he told POLITICO in an interview.

“No,” he said when asked whether he was being sought after to lead the powerful Berlin-based Association of the Automotive Industry (VDA), which represents industry giants such as Volkswagen, Daimler and BMW.

German media this month revisited persistent speculation that Oettinger could return to Berlin when his mandate ends in Brussels to later take on the job at the VDA. The mandate for current President Bernhard Mattes ends in 2020.

Oettinger, a longtime supporter of the automotive industry who championed its interests in his previous role as digital commissioner, said he had turned down the job previously. He said he was approached about replacing former VDA boss Matthias Wissmann, an ex-federal transport minister and ally to Chancellor Angela Merkel, who vacated the lobbying role in 2018.

“I said no, because the mandate in the [Jean-Claude] Juncker [Commission] is ongoing and it’s a five-year mandate, it was clear, I’m here in Brussels,” he said.

The two-time commissioner and former prime minister of the German state of Baden-Württemberg — home to Porsche and Daimler — said he has other plans for a private sector career once he leaves the Berlaymont next month, but declined to elaborate.
description: The longtime supporter of the automotive industry says he had turned down such a job in the past.
